Hi everyone, I'm trying to install Ubuntu 10.10 but the option to "Use the largest continuous  free space has been removed.. could anyone help me partition manually?
do you need to keep windows or any other os? or data?
I just need to keep Windows 7 which is  on it's own partition. I purposely left myself free unallocated space on the hdd for this install
there is a option to install side by side with windows
I'd rather it be on a separate partition though ... that option tried to combine them side by side
I'm just confused with how to set up my root, swap and home partitions because all the documentation on the web conflicts each other
oh ok, do you plan to install any other linux distro, or do you plan to ever reinstall ubuntu?
Ubuntu will be my first attempt working under Linux so I really don't know if I plan to or not .. it's best to assume I might
ok, then you need 2 partitions, how much space did you give?
I have 40.3gb of free space to work with

ok you need a / (root) partition and a /home partition, the root should be around 8+ or up to 15-16gb, its dependant on how much applications you plan to install (i'd say 12gb is fine) then the rest for /home (which will be your userspace containing your personal data including application settings for your user
So I won't be needing a swap/virtual memory partition at all?
a swap file is just as fine (apparantly equal speeds on some sata hdds), how much ram do you have?
then a swap file should be fine, just for hibernation etc
Thanks man --  the install is underway!
